connection_tab.bootstrap_server_description: Establish the initial connection between your client and Kafka instance.
connection_tab.create_service_account_to_generate_crede: Create a service account to generate credentials. Manage the service accounts you create on the <value>Service Accounts</value> page.
connection_tab.current_instance: Accounts do not have access to this instance unless granted under the instanceâ€™s <value>Access tab</value>. The owner, the organization administrator, or users with the Allow Alter permission on this instance can manage access.
connection_tab.drawer_resource_tab_body_description_1: Your application or tool initially connects to the Kafka instance using the bootstrap server and authenticates with your service account credentials. You can also access the Kafka instance by calling the REST API using a token obtained from Red Hat SSO.
connection_tab.kafka_instance_url_button_aria_label: More information about the URL for Kafka Instance API
connection_tab.kafka_instance_url_description: Configure topics, consumer groups, and access for this Kafka instance.
connection_tab.kafka_instance_url_popover_body: Use the REST API URL to connect to this Kafka instance to manage topics, consumer groups, and access.
connection_tab.kafka_management_button_aria_label: More information about the URL for Kafka Management API
connection_tab.kafka_management_description: Manage Kafka instances and service accounts, and access metrics.
connection_tab.kafka_management_popover_body: Use the REST API URL to connect to manage Kafka instances and service accounts, and to access metrics.
connection_tab.rest_api_description: Streams for Apache Kafka provides two REST APIs, one for accessing the Kafka instance and one for managing resources such as Kafka instances and services accounts.
connection_tab.sasl_oauthbearer_description: Use your service account credentials and a token endpoint URL to authenticate your client with the Kafka instance.
connection_tab.sasl_oauthbearer_popover_content: OpenShift Streams for Apache Kafka uses the industry-standard OAuth protocol via the SASL/OAUTHBEARER provided by Apache Kafka.
connection_tab.sasl_plain_description: Use your service account credentials (Client ID and Client secret) as the user name and password to authenticate your client with the Kafka instance.

consumerGroup.consumer_group_delete_message: The {{name}} consumer group will be deleted.
consumerGroup.delete_consumer_connected_alert_body: One or more members are currently connected to a topic. All members of a consumer group that are connected to a topic must be disconnected before deleting the consumer group.
consumerGroup.delete_consumer_connected_alert_title: The {{name}} consumer group cannot be deleted at this time
consumerGroup.empty_consumer_body: When configuring an application client to access Kafka, assign a group ID to associate the consumer with a consumer group.
consumerGroup.offset_successfully_reset: offsets for the consumer group have been successfully reset
consumerGroup.partitions_with_lag_description: Partitions with lag shows the number of partitions where the assigned consumer has not caught up with the last message in the partition. The offset lag of a partition reflects the current offset position of a consumer in relation to the end of the partition log. Use this number to identify any delay in the consumption of messages. To reduce consumer lag, you typically add new consumers to a group.
consumerGroup.partitions_with_lag_for_topic: Partitions with lag in this topic
consumerGroup.reset_offset_accept: I understand that by resetting the offset position, I risk clients skipping or duplicating messages.
consumerGroup.reset_offset_connected_alert_body: One or more members of the consumer group are currently connected to a topic. All members of a consumer group must be disconnected before resetting the offset.
consumerGroup.reset_offset_connected_alert_title: The offset for this consumer group cannot be reset at this time
consumerGroup.topic_table_aria: table for consumer groups by topic

delete_instance_message: The <0>{{instanceName}}</0> Kafka instance and all topics will be deleted. Applications will no longer have access to the topics in this instance.
delete_topic_active_message: One or more consumers are currently active in this topic, and will be removed at the time of deletion.
delete_topic_message: The <0>{{instanceName}}</0> topic will be deleted and removed from this instance. Applications will no longer have access to this topic.
empty_state_no_instances_body: For help getting started, access the <0>quick start guide</0>
empty_state_no_results_found_body: Adjust your filters and try again, or <0>clear all filters</0>.
input_field_invalid_message: Valid characters include lowercase letters from a to z, numbers from 0 to 9, and hyphens ( - ).
max_filter_message: Maximum number of filters reached. Clear a filter before adding another.
no_permission_to_change_owner: Organization administrators and the Kafka instance owner can change the owner of an instance.
no_permission_to_delete_kafka: Organization administrators and the Kafka instance owner can delete this instance.
owner_field_invalid_message: Red Hat Login ID cannot contain spaces, national characters or the following special characters " $ ^ < > | + % / ; : , * = ~ # ( )

sample_code.bracket_text: Update values in brackets (< >) with your own values.
sample_code.code_snippet_description: Use our sample code snippets to learn how to connect client applications to your Kafka instance. First, modify our configuration code to make a secure connection to your Kafka instance. Then, use our application code to create example producers and consumers that interact with your instance.
sample_code.sample_configuration_code_description: Use the following sample configuration code to make a secure connection to your Kafka instance.
sample_code.sample_consumer_code_description: Use the following application code to create an example {{client_type}} client that consumes messages from your Kafka instance.
sample_code.sample_producer_code_description: Use the following application code to create an example {{client_type}} client that produces messages to your Kafka instance.
sample_code.spring_boot_consumer_configuration_descr: Use the following code to create a listener container required by the example Spring Boot consumer.
sample_code.spring_boot_consumer_description: Use the following code to run the example Spring Boot consumer.
sample_code.spring_boot_listener_description: Use the following code to run the listener container required by the example Spring Boot consumer.
sample_code.spring_boot_sample_consumer_code_descrip: Use the following code snippets to create an example Spring Boot client that consumes messages from your Kafka instance.

settings.error_alert_title_description: We're unable to update connection re-authentication at this time. Try again later.
settings.kafka_instance_settings_label: Configure global settings for this Kafka instance.
settings.warning_description: There are potential risks associated with turning off re-authentication, where attackers could stay connected indefinitely.

status_warning_or_error_title: This is taking longer than expected.
suspend_empty_state_body: Most actions are unavailable with a suspended instance.
suspend_popover_body_1: The subscription associated with this instance is no longer active.
will_expire: This trial instance will expire in <time>{{time}}</time>
